description.p: “I have tried to find one, and yet they have all eluded me. These monsters are more trouble than they are worth to me. Yet, I’d love to study one someday. If the stories are true and they are able to rejuvenate their bodies with the blood of others, that could be a truly magnificent step in the direction of the second stage of soul transfusion. No matter. If I’ve yet to find one then it may be for the best. I’m not sure I’d want to see one up close anyway for I’m not sure even I could stop one.”
- Y. Mageshell, Manyhals of Death.

Ancient followers of the blood god, Hemaplousis, the Saphir were granted both immense power and an unending curse. Once mortal men, the now sharp toothed and blodless saphir have access to an unending life if they can keep paying their weight in blood to their patron. Their pale skin shines under the moonlight in which they hunt their next sacrifice and, at dawn, there’s either a corpse on the street, or a new saphir with an eternal debt to pay.

It’s unknown when the first saphirs emerged into this world, but it was during ancient times. Throughout history some have been slain by knights, mages and divine followers, but some of the originals and their “offspring” survive to the present day. They have witnessed countless days and ages, have seen the rise and fall of empires, cultures and philosophies. They have been given the gift of agelessness, but their mind is still as fragile as it always was. Most of the first saphir went mad with the weigth of their own memories, while others found ways to combat their impending insanity by various means such as magic and exile. They have seen almost all of mortal history, but most of it has been lost to their minds so they can keep themselves sane and functional. Now the only way that history is not completly lost is if at least one chose to pass their knowledge to something truly immortal, like a journal or a book.

To become a saphir, one must be drained of all of their blood and that blood must be offered to Hemaplousis by another saphir or the god itself. This lack of blood grants saphir a distinctly pale and emaciated skin. They don’t bleed when wounded, instead spilling sand from their veins. The older the saphir is the whiter their hair and iris becomes, along with the rest of their eyes becoming red. Sharp fangs cover their mouth to enable their consumption of blood. Although most of the blood they consume comes from humanoids, as it’s the most powerful, hunting for beasts and dragons is not unheard of.

Most Saphir are ancient beings with ancient names. Those who have been more recently transform either keep their birth name or adopt a new one once they accept their new nature. Normally, saphir names end with “crad” as it was the ancient word for blood and are preceded by any combination of two syllables, such as Alucrad, Fericrad and some don’t follow this norm, such as Baranor, Volomir and Zariu.
Saphir seem to have been blessed with an assortment of new abilities when turned.
Ability Score Increase. You may choose to increase an ability score by 2 and one other ability score by one or increase three different ability scores by 1.
Age. Once turned into a Saphir you cease aging. It is unknown for how long a Saphir can truly live.
Creature Type. You are an Undead.
Size. The size of Saphir is dependent on their previous life and there doesn’t seem to be any effect on neither height nor weight when transformed. Your size is either Small or Medium.
Speed. Your base walking speed is 35 feet.

Sunlight Sensitivity. The dark arts that made you into a Saphir have made it so direct sunlight is toxic towards you. You have disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.

Darkvision. Accustomed to dark dungeons and dim temples, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness as shades of crimson.

Goredrinker. When you hit a creature, that isn’t an undead or construct, with a melee weapon attack you may drink the blood resulting from that wound. After doing so you regain hit point equal to double your level plus your constituition modifier. If you have been hit with radiant damage or are under direct sunlight you cannot use this feature until the start of your next turn. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Shapechanger. Once per short rest you may transform into a tiny bat. While in this form you maintain your cognitive abilities, but aren’t able to speak. Anything you are wearing transforms with you, but nothing you are carrying does. You revert back to your true form if you die.
Languages. You can speak, read and write two languages of your choice.
For more details and updates, visit: https://homebrewery.naturalcrit.com/share/d7R6ynajmmqm

Many creatures in the worlds of D&D, especially those that dwell underground, have darkvision. Within a specified range, a creature with darkvision can see in darkness as if the darkness were dim light, so areas of darkness are only lightly obscured as far as that creature is concerned. However, you discern colors in that darkness as shades of crimson.
